thread.title: Captain Sam Cooper smashes Star University to opening-round Twenty20 win
thread.title_full: Captain Sam Cooper smashes Star University to opening-round Twenty20 win

author: Aaron Goile
title: Captain Sam Cooper smashes Star University to opening-round Twenty20 win
text:
Captain Sam Cooper smashes Star University to opening-round Twenty20 win AARON GOILE Last updated 14:30, February 1 2017 MARK TAYLOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
Sam Cooper had a tremendous outing for Star University in the first round of Hamilton club cricket's Twenty20 competition. 
The change in format did just the trick for Star University after they surged to a stunning nine-wicket win over Melville in the opening round of Hamilton club cricket's Richard Dodunski Trophy Twenty20 competition on Tuesday evening. 
Languishing in bottom place in the Eddy Marr Bowl one-day and two-day Sa ï»¿ turday competition, Star are however defending T20 champs, and they showed why in a brutal demolition at Galloway Park, thanks in no small part to captain Sam Cooper. 
With Hamilton Cricket trialling the midweek twilight timeslot after the competition was rained out in October, Star showed their liking for an after-work hitout, as they dismissed Melville for a paltry 106, before chasing down their target in just the seventh over. 
After winning the toss and batting, Melville were unable to gather any momentum, losing wickets regularly, with only three players reaching double figures and Freddy Walker's 28 off 31 being the best offering. 
READ MORE: Top three continue winning ways 
Cooper mixed Star's bowlers up, using eight in total, with the last of those being himself, who proved the most effective. Having suffered from back problems, the former seamer has turned to left-arm chinaman, and claimed a splendid 3-15 off three overs. He then also produced two runouts, as Melville crumbled to be all out in 18.3 overs. 
Then, as if he could smell dinner in the oven, Cooper wasted absolutely no time in getting his troops home, as he smashed an unbeaten 79 off just 26 balls to mow down the target. 
With a stunning strike rate of 303.85, Cooper smote 13 fours and three sixes - that was 70 runs off 16 balls just there - as he went primarily down the ground, everywhere from over mid-off to over mid-wicket, to wrap things up in just 6.3 overs. 
The other two matches also produced one-sided affairs, with Old Boys and Marist-Suburbs beating Hamilton Boys' High School and Fraser-Tech, respectively. 
Old Boys eased to a seven-wicket win at the school ground after being set less than three figures. Ad Feedback 
After sending HBHS in Old Boys captain Jono McNeill (1-1 off two) struck with the first ball of the match, before Cooper Rowell (3-15 off four) took two in the second over, as the hosts tumbled to a shocking 17-6. 
In the end Bodie Hodges' 45 not out saw HBHS bat out their overs, but they finished on a lousy 83-9, which Old Boys chased down with 5.1 overs to spare. 
Marist-Suburbs posted the only decent score of the round, notching 161-9 at Galloway Park after choosing to bat, with Peter Bocock (52 off 34, including four fours) and Matt Wallbank (40 off 30, featuring six fours) sharing in a 72-run stand for the fourth wicket to set up the total. 
In reply Marist-Suburbs' bowlers proved too tough to get away, and Tech fell behind the run rate - just 49-3 at the halfway point. 
Ryan Smith, at No 7, gave them hope in smashing 41 off just 16 (four sixes) and taking 23 off off-spinner Gogal Basu in the 15th over, but he was out in the next over, with Tech finishing on 118-9 and going down by 43 runs. 
AT A GLANCE Richard Dodunski Trophy, Rd 1 
Melville 106 (S Cooper 3-15, T Shuker 2-11) lost to Star University 110-1 (S Cooper 79no) by nine wickets. 
HBHS 83-9 (B Hodges 45no; C Rowell 3-15, S Singh 2-15) lost to Old Boys 84-3 by seven wickets. 
Marist-Suburbs 161-9 (P Bocock 52, M Wallbank 40; S Perera 3-25, J Baker 2-32) beat Fraser-Tech 118-9 (R Smith 41, N Trebilcock 34; K Hill 3-19, A Clare 2-23, G Basu 2-39) by 43 runs. - Stuff
